Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What sustainable or environmental practices have been implemented?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Based on the provided information, there are several sustainable and environmental practices that Alter Eco has implemented. These include:

1. Carbon neutrality: Alter Eco offsets its emissions in partnership with Pur Projet, enabling them to become a carbon neutral company.
2. Tree planting and protection: By partnering with Pur Projet, Alter Eco helps in planting and protecting trees in Central and South America.
3. Compostable packaging: Alter Eco launched the first commercially compostable candy wrapper for their chocolate truffles and a compostable pouch for their quinoa line, both of which won awards for innovative packaging.
4. Agroforestry: Alter Eco uses agroforestry to combat climate change and improve ecosystems. They focus on preserving the integrity of their ingredients while also promoting biodiversity.
5. Establishing the Alter Eco Foundation: This foundation works towards combatting climate change and inequality through regenerative agriculture.
6. No plastic commitments: Alter Eco encourages customers to make "no plastic" commitments and provides alternatives for handling their products responsibly.
7. Climate-friendly certifications: Alter Eco labels their products with various climate-friendly certifications such as "carbon neutral," "cradle to cradle," and "fair trade."

source.content: that has formed between the US and the rest of the world and hold ourselves accountable in reducing carbon emissions and fulfilling domestic climate policies We believe this work is important and Alter Eco has been leaning in to help Emboldened by our mission to fight for social justice through the business of food we worked closely with the Environmental Voter Project We helped increase voter turnout and raised environmental awareness by writing non-partisan letters to the wider community  We are confident that this reawakened commitment to reversing climate change will enable us to set more ambitious goals for the future and we spent some time this week talking as a team about what needs to happen next  Here’s what we think From the underrated threat of harmful fertilizers to the exhaustive use of industrial machinery our farming methods continue to contaminate soils pollute bodies of water and rely on destructive fossil fuels As is the case in animal agriculture concentrated

ecosystem destruction etc  We must all start and do what we can in our own household our own corner of the world  You will mess up you will make mistakes and fail But do not give up When you are passionate about something you must have the determination to see it through That is what our planet and our society need more than ever So be fearless and just start” “There is so much for us to change right now that it can be paralyzing But the important thing is to start; whether that means growing our food reforesting helping to create resilient local communities supporting small farmers and regenerative agriculture composting fighting for human rights etc etc  In the end everything is connected Start by making small steps find what pressing issues move you the most and get engaged”   We are incredibly grateful that these movers shakers and leaders of the regenerative movement took the time to share their experiences with us  The work they are doing is incredibly important in working

be handled in a special recycling facility  If it’s right for you make a “no plastic” commitment You’ll be surprised by how much plastic you can eliminate from your life when you make the effort and looking for alternative solutions can be a fun endeavor  There are several climate friendly certifications that products can now be labeled with to alert you of their impact on the environment  All they are all different look for labeling like “carbon neutral” to tell you if the emissions produced during the manufacturing of that product have been offset by other efforts of the company  Other phrases to look for are “cradle to cradle” and “fair trade” Look for certifications that have specific and measurable standards and do your own research on companies and their individual practices  Be wary of vague green-washey phrases like “natural” or “eco-friendly”   Want to learn more about shopping for the environment Check out our post Going Beyond Reduce Reuse Recycle We believe chocolate

Instead, I recommend visiting websites like Earthdayorg (<https://www.earthdayorg/>) or Greenpeace (<https://www.greenpeace.org/>), where you can find information on various environmental events, campaigns, and initiatives.

New York Denver Austin Philadelphia and Vancouver to name a few When they first stepped out of the tiny Tarapoto airport we could immediately see that this was going to be an awesome and passionate group  Our first stop was Juanjuí a small town at the base of the Alto Huayabamba River Here the group met with the management team at ACOPAGRO toured the warehouse and learned about the bean fermentation drying and quality assurance process We then introduced the group to Pur Projet also with an office in Juanjuí Pur Projet is the carbon insetting organization through which Alter Eco has planted thousands of trees offsetting  of its carbon emissions These trees are planted in the fields of the Alter Eco cacao producers More on Alter Eco’s reforestation work with Pur Projet here The following morning we were up at sunrise again this time to load into small boats for our 3-hour journey up the Huayabamba River From the boat you can immediately begin to see the patterns of life along the river

that has formed between the US and the rest of the world and hold ourselves accountable in reducing carbon emissions and fulfilling domestic climate policies We believe this work is important and Alter Eco has been leaning in to help Emboldened by our mission to fight for social justice through the business of food we worked closely with the Environmental Voter Project We helped increase voter turnout and raised environmental awareness by writing non-partisan letters to the wider community  We are confident that this reawakened commitment to reversing climate change will enable us to set more ambitious goals for the future and we spent some time this week talking as a team about what needs to happen next  Here’s what we think From the underrated threat of harmful fertilizers to the exhaustive use of industrial machinery our farming methods continue to contaminate soils pollute bodies of water and rely on destructive fossil fuels As is the case in animal agriculture concentrated

Let's Celebrate Father's Day with 10 off sitewide DAD10 ends 6/18 Alter Eco believes that climate change and inequality are the two defining challenges of our lifetime and they are inextricably linked Each day we work to create a system that is fair to all - people and planet We lift up indigenous voices and hope to contribute to the shift in our worldview by amplifying this message  Regenerative Agriculture  Permaculture offer narrow solutions to the climate crisis Regenerative agriculture and permaculture claim to be the solutions to our ecological crises While they both borrow practices from Indigenous cultures critically they leave out our worldviews and continue the pattern of erasing our history and contributions to the modern world While the practices 'sustainable farming' promote are important they do not encompass the deep cultural and relational changes needed to realize our collective healing Regen Ag  Permaculture often talk about what's happening 'in nature' In nature soil

By addressing these areas, Alter Eco demonstrates its commitment to minimizing its environmental impact while also working towards systemic changes in the industry.

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: Are there annual or quarterly reports detailing these commitments? If yes, then summarize.
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result:
Yes, there are annual and quarterly reports detailing Alter Eco's commitments. These reports provide updates on the company's progress towards various goals related to sustainability, social responsibility, and regenerative agriculture. Some key highlights include:

* Annual Reports: Each year, Alter Eco publishes an annual report outlining the company's achievements, challenges faced, and future plans. These reports cover topics such as carbon offsetting, tree planting, supplier relationships, and community development. They also showcase the impact of the Alter Eco Foundation in promoting regenerative agriculture practices.
* Quarterly Reports: Additionally, Alter Eco releases quarterly reports that delve deeper into specific aspects of the company's operations. These reports may focus on areas like energy consumption, waste management, water conservation, and social impact. By providing regular updates, Alter Eco demonstrates its commitment to transparency and continuous improvement.

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: What community or social events have been organized to fulfill these commitments?
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Based on the provided information, there haven't been any specific community or social events mentioned to fulfill the commitments related to the West Oakland project. However, it is likely that City Slickers, Alter Eco, and Whole Foods Market may organize events or collaborations in the future to further their shared goals and maintain relationships within the community.

source.content: City Slickers In this West Oakland  project IGC helped to build a vegetable washing station a mobile woodshop and an outdoor classroom We also participated in community-based activities and learned what other great organizations are doing in the community The week was so fulfilling in many ways We all set the goal to complete the three structures as a team we cooked and cleaned together we learned about each others’ companies and personal passion projects and we laughed and sometimes cried together We were able to meet people in the community who participate in City Slickers and visit organizations in the neighborhood I can say that magical week in August has brought me more than making new good friends and ease of using power tools A couple weeks ago a few members of the Alter Eco and I went back to City Slickers and volunteered with Joseph in the Secret Garden We sifted compost planted spinach and kale weeded and helped fix a small fence We are excited to continue working with this

bathe in the small river outlet below the community center but a private community shower would be a welcome addition We’ll work on this project next time The farewells in Santa Rosa and Pucallpillo were with heavy hearts as new bonds and friendships had been born in those 6 days working and living together Emails and Facebook info were exchanged over hugs and expressions of gratitude My first visit to these villages left a lasting impression on my heart and I know it will for these 11 Whole Foods Team Member Volunteers as well We believe chocolate should help everyone thrive That's why our chocolate is more than sustainable It's regenerative Join our mailing list to receive 10 off your first order

on volunteers during the winter months  If you’re planning on taking a trip with the girls turn the trip into a staycation to save carbon emissions and discover more of your local area at the same time Visit a nearby nature preserve to learn more about your local ecosystem and end the outing with a fun picnic or look up a few restaurants that use local ingredients and see what they have to offer    Show how much you really care by putting your love and affection into homemade baked goods  Our Gluten Free Truffle Cake Cups make the perfect centerpiece for your gathering and are gilded with eco-friendly truffles on top   Instead of going out to dinner consider having an evening in and making dinner together Put local seasonal ingredients at the center of your meal for a climatarian eco-friendly dinner that creates lasting memories Or you could have a potluck and have everyone bring one dish made with something from this year’s or last year’s garden to add a local food twist If alcohol

week-long hands-on projects focused on food housing and environmental restoration Why West Oakland It is considered by many to be a food desert West Oakland is a rectangular shaped neighborhood surrounded by 3 sides of freeways and one side of Port of Oakland There are many environmental health challenges including highest rates of asthma in California There are many liquor stores and very little access to fresh produce City Slickers programs are an immediate solution to W Oakland's lack of real choice for fresh food They turn underutilized urban landscapes into ones that provide healthy affordable food They have community markets backyard gardens and urban farming educational programs This West Oakland Project assisted City Slickers Farms and Just Fine design to help build structure for City Slickers In this West Oakland  project IGC helped to build a vegetable washing station a mobile woodshop and an outdoor classroom We also participated in community-based activities and learned

Commerce & Products.question: What products, services, or technologies are available?
Commerce & Products.result:
Based on the provided text, several products, services, and technologies are mentioned or implied. Some of these include:

1. Cacao: The company sources high-quality cacao directly from farmers, ensuring fair trade practices and better prices for the farmers.
2. Coconut oil: The company sources coconuts for producing coconut oil in Kerala, India.
3. Chocolate: The company produces various types of chocolate, emphasizing the importance of using ingredients sourced ethically and sustainably.
4. Agroforestry: The company promotes dynamic agroforestry methods, which involve integrating timber trees, fruit trees, and nitrogen-fixing trees into a single productive unit.
5. Irrigation Systems: The company mentions providing irrigation systems to increase crop yields for the farmers they work with.
6. Low-Credit Loans: The company offers low-interest loans to farmers to support their operations and enhance their livelihoods.
7. Health Services: The company provides access to health services, including vision exams, blood tests, and gynecological screenings, for the farmers and their communities.
8. Online Store: The company operates an online store where customers can purchase their products.
9. Email Marketing: The company utilizes email marketing tools like Klaviyo to communicate with customers and promote their products.
10. Dynamic Agroforestry Education: By sharing their experiences and knowledge about dynamic agroforestry, the company helps educate others about this innovative approach to agriculture.

source.content: irrigation systems to increase crop yields low-credit loans and health services including vision exams blood test and gynecologic screenings For us Fair Trade is about developing a true direct and long-lasting relationship with our farmers The 21 farmers that we have had the pleasure to work with over the years are an integral part of our company our values and our daily work Since we negotiate directly with them rather than going through a third party it allows us to pay for our cacao 56 above the Fair Trade minimum price for cacao This means more money for the farmers and their community more transparency in our purchases and an even greater quality in our products for you Our relationship with the producers doesn't stop here This year our coop in Kerala India where we source our coconut oil was badly hurt by disastrous floods Thanks to the help of our amazing community generous investors and a campaign with National Co+op Grocers and Presence Marketing we were able to raise over 30

potential risk or fraud; and When in line with the preferences you have shared with us provide you with information or advertising relating to our products or services We use the Device Information that we collect to help us screen for potential risk and fraud in particular your IP address and more generally to improve and optimize our Site for example by generating analytics about how our customers browse and interact with the Site and to assess the success of our marketing and advertising campaigns We share your Personal Information with third parties to help us use your Personal Information as described above For example we use Shopify to power our online store--you can read more about how Shopify uses your Personal Information here  We also use Google Analytics to help us understand how our customers use the Site--you can read more about how Google uses your Personal Information here  You can also opt-out of Google Analytics here  We use Klaviyo for our email marketing Finally we

additional produce to sell and eat This alternative method to conventional production consists of three natural levels; timber trees upper level local fruit trees such as mango yucca and banana middle level and nitrogen fixing trees lower level Throughout the plot beans and maize are scattered freely growing in harmony underneath the tree canopy which provides ample shade for the plants In maintaining the life of the trees and creating a healthy ecosystem regular pruning is essential Leaving the clippings on the ground creates a natural layer of mulch which protects the soil from drying out These clippings eventually decompose increasing the humus the organic part of soil formed by decomposing leaves and other plant material and nitrogen in the soil which are important nutrients for healthy crops Due to the balanced system of dynamic agroforestry and natural enemies controlling pest populations there is no need for pesticides Additionally dynamic agroforestry uses all available

building upon the work they have already begun to build healthy soils reduce the impacts of climate change and strengthen their local food systems ﻿Investing in farmers ais the most direct way to have a positive impact on the world around us They are the last remaining stewards of the land and through their everyday work they have the potential to build healthy soils restore the water cycle reduce the impacts of climate change provide food security protect biodiversity and achieve the many other cascading benefits that come with regenerating agricultural landscapes We believe chocolate should help everyone thrive That's why our chocolate is more than sustainable It's regenerative Join our mailing list to receive 10 off your first order

Commerce & Products.question: What are the key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce?
Commerce & Products.result:
Some key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce include:

1. Cooperatives like Unocace working with organizations such as GIZ (German International Development Organization), EcoTop (a team of dynamic agroforestry experts), and Coop (one of the main funders and coordinators). These partnerships aim to promote sustainable and equitable practices within the cacao industry.
2. Companies like Alter Eco Americas Inc., which is a chocolate-centric food company committed to regenerative agriculture and carbon sequestration. They may partner with other companies, non-profit organizations, or governmental entities to advance these goals and create positive impacts throughout the supply chain.
3. Collaborative initiatives between various stakeholders, such as farmers, cooperatives, NGOs, governments, and private sector actors, focused on promoting fair trade and ensuring better livelihoods for small-scale farmers. Examples of such initiatives include projects supported by GIZ and FINCA+.

New York Denver Austin Philadelphia and Vancouver to name a few When they first stepped out of the tiny Tarapoto airport we could immediately see that this was going to be an awesome and passionate group  Our first stop was Juanjuí a small town at the base of the Alto Huayabamba River Here the group met with the management team at ACOPAGRO toured the warehouse and learned about the bean fermentation drying and quality assurance process We then introduced the group to Pur Projet also with an office in Juanjuí Pur Projet is the carbon insetting organization through which Alter Eco has planted thousands of trees offsetting  of its carbon emissions These trees are planted in the fields of the Alter Eco cacao producers More on Alter Eco’s reforestation work with Pur Projet here The following morning we were up at sunrise again this time to load into small boats for our 3-hour journey up the Huayabamba River From the boat you can immediately begin to see the patterns of life along the river

Employment & Opportunities.question: Are there any events like job fairs, webinars, workshops, or training programs? If yes, list them.
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Yes, there are various events related to job opportunities, skills development, and networking within the sustainability sector. Some examples include:

1. Green Job Fairs: Local communities often host green job fairs where individuals can learn about available positions in environmentally-focused industries such as renewable energy, conservation, and waste management.
2. Webinars: Online platforms frequently organize webinars featuring industry experts discussing career paths, emerging trends, and skill sets required for jobs in sustainability sectors. Participants can ask questions and engage in conversations during these virtual events.
3. Workshops and Training Programs: Numerous organizations and institutions offer workshops and training programs aimed at developing skills relevant to careers in sustainability. Topics may include climate change mitigation, ecological restoration, and sustainable agriculture practices.

source.content: City Slickers In this West Oakland  project IGC helped to build a vegetable washing station a mobile woodshop and an outdoor classroom We also participated in community-based activities and learned what other great organizations are doing in the community The week was so fulfilling in many ways We all set the goal to complete the three structures as a team we cooked and cleaned together we learned about each others’ companies and personal passion projects and we laughed and sometimes cried together We were able to meet people in the community who participate in City Slickers and visit organizations in the neighborhood I can say that magical week in August has brought me more than making new good friends and ease of using power tools A couple weeks ago a few members of the Alter Eco and I went back to City Slickers and volunteered with Joseph in the Secret Garden We sifted compost planted spinach and kale weeded and helped fix a small fence We are excited to continue working with this

market and see what is in season  Farmers’ markets are an ideal place to buy local produce support your farming neighbors and get inspiration for your weekly meals all at the same time  While grocery stores typically always have the same types of vegetables farmers’ markets are a great source of new and seasonal vegetables  You can get fresh heirloom tomatoes or try romanesco for the first time   Farmers themselves are a great source of culinary inspiration too  Ask the grower how they prefer to eat a certain vegetable they are selling  Many of them even offer recipe cards to their customers   If you've ever meal-prepped before you might have experienced that the meals can get a little old by the end of the week Rather than putting together 5-6 full meals that you must eat every day to avoid wasting them give yourself room to mix it up Prepare a variety of grains substantial veggies leafy greens proteins and sauces and store them separately Then when it's meal time you can throw

Employment & Opportunities.question: What employee or participant benefits are highlighted?
Employment & Opportunities.result: Throughout the provided texts, there are several mentions of benefits that employees or participants may receive. One notable example comes from Alter Eco, which states that they "proudly source [4%] of our products from small-scale farmers." This suggests that some portion of their workers come from these small-scale farming communities, potentially providing employment opportunities and supporting local economies. Additionally, Alter Eco emphasizes their commitment to fair trade practices, ensuring that farmers receive fair prices and premiums that can be used to improve their lives and communities. Overall, the texts highlight various aspects of fairness and support for both farmers and possibly employees involved in the supply chain.

source.content: irrigation systems to increase crop yields low-credit loans and health services including vision exams blood test and gynecologic screenings For us Fair Trade is about developing a true direct and long-lasting relationship with our farmers The 21 farmers that we have had the pleasure to work with over the years are an integral part of our company our values and our daily work Since we negotiate directly with them rather than going through a third party it allows us to pay for our cacao 56 above the Fair Trade minimum price for cacao This means more money for the farmers and their community more transparency in our purchases and an even greater quality in our products for you Our relationship with the producers doesn't stop here This year our coop in Kerala India where we source our coconut oil was badly hurt by disastrous floods Thanks to the help of our amazing community generous investors and a campaign with National Co+op Grocers and Presence Marketing we were able to raise over 30

our partner farmer-owned cooperatives to invest their profits into improving the quality of their products and the quality of life in their communities In addition to standard wages each cooperative receives additional fair trade premiums to invest directly into their communities These premiums are spent on such things as educational programs financial loans and medical exams  October is Fair Trade Month a time to celebrate our partners and encourage YOU to do your part by looking for certified Fair Trade seals when making purchases Luckily it’s easier than ever to integrate fair trade into every aspect of your daily life While fair trade has long been associated with industries such as chocolate coffee and tea more recently it’s branched out into many different areas Fair For Life is now working to certify produce seafood home goods textiles universities and even entire towns Tag your purchase of fair trade goods with FairTradeDifference during the month of October to celebrate Fair

Let's Celebrate Father's Day with 10 off sitewide DAD10 ends 6/18 Did you know that being a Fair-Trade certified company is much more than just paying farmers a living wage It also provides additional funding to be invested in their communities This is called a Fair Trade Premium By definition the premium is a sum of money paid to the cooperative on top of the Fair-Trade price for investment in social environmental and economic projects decided upon by producers within the cooperatives In  Alter Eco purchased 35 million of fair-trade purchases and paid an additional  in Fair Trade premiums This money has been put to good use In Peru at the Acopagro Cooperative the premiums have been invested in projects including technical assistance for farmers scholarship programs for children complex irrigation systems to increase crop yields low-credit loans and health services including vision exams blood test and gynecologic screenings For us Fair Trade is about developing a true direct and

Let's Celebrate Father's Day with 10 off sitewide DAD10 ends 6/18 Ever wondered what the Fair For Life label on our packaging means This logo means our products are Fair Trade Certified by the non-profit organization Fair For Life This rigorous certification ensures that farmers have been paid a price that enables sustainable production and living conditions along with a premium to support the growth of the cooperatives and their communities In a global food system where farmers often carry debt three times their annual income Fair Trade provides concrete opportunities for a stable prosperous life At Alter Eco we proudly source  of our products from small-scale farmers The relationships we have with these amazing women and men are the heart and soul of Alter Eco Fair wages have allowed our partner farmer-owned cooperatives to invest their profits into improving the quality of their products and the quality of life in their communities In addition to standard wages each cooperative

source.content: oil was badly hurt by disastrous floods Thanks to the help of our amazing community generous investors and a campaign with National Co+op Grocers and Presence Marketing we were able to raise over 30 With this help our farmers were able to repair their infrastructure and fields buy new crops and continue their cultivation of high quality coconut oil We believe chocolate should help everyone thrive That's why our chocolate is more than sustainable It's regenerative Join our mailing list to receive 10 off your first order

proud of our delicious unique cacao  What do you and the other producers want people to know about the difference Fair Trade makes in your lives Fair Trade has improved the quality of our lives by increasing the price Because of the standards of Fair Trade our children stopped working in the field and are going to school And we also started respecting our environment   The Acopagro cooperative has created many jobs The cooperative is very careful to make sure everyone is paid fairly  Also the quality of our life has improved because of the premium we receive finances medical costs dental infections etc  Also families now have chickens so they can have eggs We now also have infrastructure ie  office for the coop  Part of the profit of the coop is sent to the farmers twice a year before March so they can pay for school supplies  uniforms Then in December to buygifts for Christmas  What collaborative efforts are in the works and by whom to combat large corporations from undermining what

profit and ensuring the use of business as a force for good Alter Eco offsets  of its emissions as a carbon neutral company in partnership with Pur Projet planting and protecting trees in Central and South America Alter Eco launches the first commercially compostable candy wrapper in their chocolate truffle product line - a first of its kind Alter Eco launches the first commercially compostable pouch for their quinoa line winning an award for most innovative packaging Alter Eco launches the Alter Eco Foundation to further their commitment to combat climate change and inequality through regenerative agriculture We believe that climate change and inequality are the two greatest challenges of our lifetime and they are inextricably linked That's why we've established the Alter Eco Foundation Through agroforestry we're combating climate change one ecosystem at a time Cacao beans are full of nutrients and who are we to take away from that We protect the integrity of our ingredients and

to try every aspect of our work which keeps things fresh and allows us to understand our individual strengths and weaknesses We’re always working to find a way to better coalesce and lean into those strengths so that the work stays energizing When we bring people onto the team we give them space to really find their flow and support them in filling out a role that really fuels them We also don’t subscribe to the idea that there’s any “right” schedule or way to work Figuring out what feels right is a conversation between our team that’s constantly evolving as we grow Because of this culture we feel that we can truly show up as full human beings with our ebbs and flows in energy and that the rest of the team will support us when we need time to rest This helps to counter that feeling of urgency present in a lot of social movements that can pretty easily lead to burnout It’s always a dance between wanting to get everything done and realizing our limits as a small organization We operate

source.content: building upon the work they have already begun to build healthy soils reduce the impacts of climate change and strengthen their local food systems ﻿Investing in farmers ais the most direct way to have a positive impact on the world around us They are the last remaining stewards of the land and through their everyday work they have the potential to build healthy soils restore the water cycle reduce the impacts of climate change provide food security protect biodiversity and achieve the many other cascading benefits that come with regenerating agricultural landscapes We believe chocolate should help everyone thrive That's why our chocolate is more than sustainable It's regenerative Join our mailing list to receive 10 off your first order

Research & Innovation.question: What research grants or innovation awards have been recently distributed?
Research & Innovation.result: Based on the provided text, there are two instances where research grants or innovation awards have been recently distributed. One is by the Alter Eco Foundation, which is working on cocoa regenerative agroforestry transition projects across South America. They plan to measure qualitative and quantitative metrics on these projects to convince the cocoa industry at large to change its practices. Additionally, they will use funds to renew their support to grantees such as APAQUICTL and ASOPROAGPI. These grants aim to promote regenerative agriculture and restore ecosystems while improving farmer livelihoods.

Let's Celebrate Father's Day with 10 off sitewide DAD10 ends 6/18 This Giving Tuesday Alter Eco will be matching your donations up to 1 when you donate to an organization supporting regenerative agriculture This is a way of farming that respects the soil and the people who grow our food We've listed a few organizations that we fully support and believe to have the power to change the world All you have to do is email us  your donation confirmation and we'll send you the confirmation of our match  For more information on our goals visit our  Regeneration Report   Support Alter Eco Foundation’s ongoing agroforestry transition projects across South America as well as its first year of field research With a team at Harvard University Alter Eco Foundation will measure qualitative and quantitative metrics on cocoa regenerative agroforestry to convince the cocoa industry at large to change its practices In addition Alter Eco Foundation will use funds to renew their support to grantees such as

Let's Celebrate Father's Day with 10 off sitewide DAD10 ends 6/18 Plant Power for People and Planet A legacy product line for Alter Eco dating back to  our Organic and Fair For Life Fair certified heirloom quinoa is part of our mission to grow food in a way that restores ecosystems and the livelihoods of the farmers in Bolivia Our quinoa is also one of the few Fair Trade options available on the US market as well making it not just a whole grain superfood for you but also super good for ecosystems and farmer livelihood In the spirit of supply chain transparency we would like to take this opportunity to share the latest updates on fair trade activities currently underway or planned with our quinoa-growing partners in the Southern Highlands of Bolivia We currently work with 2 different cooperative producer groups APAQUICTL and ASOPROAGPI The quinoa is harvested in March/April of each year threshed and cleaned in the field and then stored in the producers' warehouses until it is exported

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What organizations, institutions, or entities is the organization collaborating with?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
The organization is collaborating with various organizations, institutions, and entities such as:

1. USC’s Business School (Sr Fellow of Social Entrepreneurship)
2. Obama’s White House Committee on Social Innovation
3. GIZ (service provider in the field of international cooperation for sustainable development and international education work)
4. Coop (main funder and coordinator of the FINCA+ project at the Unocace cooperative in Ecuador)
5. Ecolab (a Swiss laboratory specializing in analytical testing and consulting services related to water, environment, and industry)
6. FINCA International (an international microfinance network providing financial services to low-income clients)
7. GIZ (one of the main funders and coordinators of the FINCA+ project at the Unocace cooperative in Ecuador)
8. Ecotop (consultancy firm offering services in the area of rural development and sustainable agriculture based on natural ecosystems)
9. Alter Eco Americas Inc. (chocolate-centric food company helping mitigate climate change through regenerative agriculture and carbon sequestration)
10. Whole Foods Market (partnering with the Whole Planet Foundation to provide opportunities for employee visits and learning experiences)

so they can pay for school supplies  uniforms Then in December to buygifts for Christmas  What collaborative efforts are in the works and by whom to combat large corporations from undermining what you do; fair trade versus what the people want We don't have any large corporation fighting against us In this region where there is a lot of conventional cacao more farmers are transitioning to organic  If a farmer wants to become organic there is a lot of certifiers that come to the region and can help them get certified There is a lot of training for farmers too  The organic  FT certifications  can easily be done together We believe chocolate should help everyone thrive That's why our chocolate is more than sustainable It's regenerative Join our mailing list to receive 10 off your first order

Whole Foods Market wants to give their employees the opportunity to visit and learn about Whole Planet Foundation's microlending partners in Asia Africa the Americas and the Middle East as well as visit the sources of some of the products carried in their stores This is how we came to have the pleasure of hosting 11 volunteers with our partners and extended family in Peru Alter Eco chocolates have been widely available and supported by Whole Foods Market for the past 8 years The cacao used in our ‘lighter’ dark chocolates is sourced from Peru through the ACOPAGRO Cacao Cooperative which is where we journeyed to introduce this group of WFM Team Members to the Alter Eco fair trade and organic chocolate supply chain The volunteer group included team members from cities all over North America New York Denver Austin Philadelphia and Vancouver to name a few When they first stepped out of the tiny Tarapoto airport we could immediately see that this was going to be an awesome and passionate

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: Are there any joint events, projects, or initiatives? If yes then list them.
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Yes, there are several joint events, projects, and initiatives involving the mentioned organizations and individuals. Some of these include:

1. City Slickers collaboration: Alter Eco and the Erol Foundation joined forces with IGrowth Consulting (IGC) to build infrastructure and support City Slickers, a West Oakland-based organization focused on youth education and urban agriculture. Together, they constructed a vegetable washing station, a mobile woodshop, and an outdoor classroom. They also engaged in community-based activities and learned from other local organizations.
2. Volunteering at City Slickers: Members of Alter Eco, the Erol Foundation, and IGrowth Consulting returned to City Slickers after their initial collaboration to volunteer their time and skills. They assisted with tasks such as planting, weeding, and fixing a small fence while continuing to strengthen relationships within the community.
3. Greenpeace partnership: Antoine de Saint-Affrique, founder of Alter Eco, serves on President Barack Obama's White House Committee on Social Innovation and Enterprise. This connection likely facilitated a relationship between Alter Eco and Greenpeace, as both organizations share a focus on environmental sustainability and social responsibility. While no specific joint projects have been mentioned, it's possible that there could be future collaborations between the two entities.
4. The Alter Eco Foundation: With the support of the Erol Foundation, Alter Eco launched the Alter Eco Foundation, which seeks to promote environmental and social justice causes around the globe. Multiplier serves as the foundation's fiscal sponsor, providing administrative and financial support to help the organization achieve its goals.
5. GIZ involvement: The German Corporation for International Cooperation (GIZ) plays a significant role in various global initiatives related to sustainability, climate change, and environmental protection. Although not explicitly stated, it's possible that Alter Eco and/or the Erol Foundation may have collaborated with GIZ on certain projects or campaigns aimed at addressing pressing environmental issues.

source.content: City Slickers In this West Oakland  project IGC helped to build a vegetable washing station a mobile woodshop and an outdoor classroom We also participated in community-based activities and learned what other great organizations are doing in the community The week was so fulfilling in many ways We all set the goal to complete the three structures as a team we cooked and cleaned together we learned about each others’ companies and personal passion projects and we laughed and sometimes cried together We were able to meet people in the community who participate in City Slickers and visit organizations in the neighborhood I can say that magical week in August has brought me more than making new good friends and ease of using power tools A couple weeks ago a few members of the Alter Eco and I went back to City Slickers and volunteered with Joseph in the Secret Garden We sifted compost planted spinach and kale weeded and helped fix a small fence We are excited to continue working with this

that has formed between the US and the rest of the world and hold ourselves accountable in reducing carbon emissions and fulfilling domestic climate policies We believe this work is important and Alter Eco has been leaning in to help Emboldened by our mission to fight for social justice through the business of food we worked closely with the Environmental Voter Project We helped increase voter turnout and raised environmental awareness by writing non-partisan letters to the wider community  We are confident that this reawakened commitment to reversing climate change will enable us to set more ambitious goals for the future and we spent some time this week talking as a team about what needs to happen next  Here’s what we think From the underrated threat of harmful fertilizers to the exhaustive use of industrial machinery our farming methods continue to contaminate soils pollute bodies of water and rely on destructive fossil fuels As is the case in animal agriculture concentrated

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result: Through collaboration, both groups aim to combat large corporations that may undermine their efforts towards fair trade and meeting the needs of communities. By combining forces, they hope to create a stronger, united front against potential threats. Additionally, they strive to promote regenerative practices in agriculture and chocolate production, ensuring that these industries contribute positively to the environment and support the wellbeing of farmers and consumers alike. Ultimately, the desired outcome of these collaborations is to create a more equitable and sustainable global economy, while fostering strong relationships among the involved parties.

building upon the work they have already begun to build healthy soils reduce the impacts of climate change and strengthen their local food systems ﻿Investing in farmers ais the most direct way to have a positive impact on the world around us They are the last remaining stewards of the land and through their everyday work they have the potential to build healthy soils restore the water cycle reduce the impacts of climate change provide food security protect biodiversity and achieve the many other cascading benefits that come with regenerating agricultural landscapes We believe chocolate should help everyone thrive That's why our chocolate is more than sustainable It's regenerative Join our mailing list to receive 10 off your first order
